Machida,a,b,z H. Maeda,b H. Peng,b and T. Shigematsua,baKonan High Technology Research Center and bDepartment of Chemistry, Konan University, Higashinada-ku, Kobe 658-8501, Japan

An all-solid-state battery was fabricated with LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 ﬁne powder as cathode materials. The LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 ﬁne powder was synthesized with oxalate decomposition methods and the average particle size of the powder was 2 mm diam. In the all-solid-state battery, a-60Li2S (cid:149) 40SiS2 powder, which was prepared by a mechanical milling process, was used as the solid electrolyte. The anode was metallic indium foil 0.127 mm thick. The charge-discharge cycling test of the battery was carried

Since Kennedy et al. reported that the melt-quenched glasses in the Li2S-SiS2 system showed high lithium-ion conductivity in the range 1023 to 1026 S cm21 at room temperature,21-26 silicon sulﬁde- based glasses have been studied extensively in an effort to improve their ion-conducting properties and electrochemical stabilities. Kondo et al. reported that Li3PO4-doped Li2S-SiS2 glasses had high lithium-ion conductivity more than 1023 S cm21 at room tempera- ture and wide electrochemical window
more than 10 V against Li metal.27-29 In addition, they reported9-12 several types of solid-state lithium cells with the glassy electrolytes system Li3PO4-Li2S-SiS2 .

Minami and Tatsumisago investigated comprehensively the dop- ing effects of several kinds of lithium oxosalts into the Li2S-SiS2 glasses on electrochemical properties, thermal stability, and struc- tural changes of the glasses.30-38 They also suggested that high- energy ballmilling, in which mechanical forces progress chemical reactions, was a very convenient way to get amorphous Li2S-SiS2 ﬁne powders.39,40 According to their reports,39,40 the amorphous ~mol %! powder with average particle size
;2 mm 60Li2S(cid:149)40SiS2 can be synthesized by the high-energy ballmilling process, and the obtained samples show high ion conductivity in the range 1023 to 1024 S cm21 at room temperature.

an a-NaFeO2-type structure the same as well-known LiCoO2 , are re- ported to have high structural stability against overcharge more than the LiCoO2 . The LiyCoO2 shows an irreversible phase transition to monoclinic at about y 5 0.55.54-57 The from hexagonal LiyCo0.3Ni0.7O2 solid solution is reported to be stable against the phase transition up to y 5 0.3. Furthermore, speciﬁc capacities of the LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 are larger than that of LiCoO2 . 41-53The LiyCo0.3Ni0.7O2

Figure 2. Schematic diagram of the all-solid-state battery with a- ~mol %! inorganic solid electrolytes. The cathode was a mix- 60Li2S(cid:149)40SiS2 ture of LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 ﬁne powder ~59 wt %!, the solid electrolytes ~39 wt %!, and acetylene black powders ~2 wt %!.

In this study, we applied oxalate decomposition methods to the preparation of LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 ﬁne powders, and fabricated solid- state lithium cells with the obtained LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 ﬁne powders as ~mol cathode materials. We also tried to prepare a-60Li2S(cid:149)40SiS2 %! lithium-ion conductor by the high-energy ballmilling process and to use the ballmilled sample as the solid electrolyte of solid-state batteries.Experimental

Lithium cobalt nickel oxides.—LiOH(cid:149)H2O, CoC2O4(cid:149)2H2O, and NiC2O4(cid:149)2H2O were used as starting materials for preparation of the LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 solid solutions. Desired amounts of the starting ma- terials were weighed and mixed by use of a ballmilling apparatus for 2 h at room temperature. Total weight of the starting materials was 3 g. During the ballmilling, H2O2 of 2 mL was added to the mixture to oxidize the transition metal ions Co21 and Ni21 into Co31 and Ni31,

respectively. The mixture was dried under vacuum for 1 h and the obtained dry powders were used as the precursor for the prepa- ration of LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 ﬁne powders. Heat-treatment of the precur- sor for 2 h at 800°C in O2 atmosphere gave the LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 powder samples. The obtained samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction ~XRD, Rigaku, RINT-2000! with Cu Ka radiation. The morphologies of samples were examined by using a scanning elec- tron microscope ~SEM, Hitachi, FEM-4500!.

Electrochemical properties of solid electrolytes.—The ballmilled ~mol %! sample powder was pressed into a 10 mma-60Li2S(cid:149)40SiS2diam pellet and nickel electrodes were attached on both sides of the pellet for electrical conductivity measurements. AC conductivity was measured in dry Ar atmosphere from 20 Hz to 1 MHz using an impedance meter ~Hewlett-Packard, HP-4284A! and the conductiv- ity was determined by employing complex impedance analysis.

Charge-discharge properties of solid-state batteries.—Figure 2 shows the schematic diagram of the solid-state cell used for inves- tigating electrochemical properties of the LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 sample. In this solid-state cell, the a-60Li2S(cid:149)40SiS2 powder prepared by the mechanical milling process was used as the solid electrolyte. The cathode was a mixture of the LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 sample ~59 wt %!, the a-60Li2S(cid:149)40SiS2 solid electrolyte ~39 wt %!, and acetylene black powders ~2 wt %!.

milling process.—XRD measurements conﬁrmed that the samples ball- milled more than 30 h at room temperature were in an amorphous state. AC conductivity measurements suggested that the 30 h ball- milled sample had a high conductivity 1.8 3 1024 S cm21 at room temperature.Solidelectrolytespreparedbymechanical

Figure 4 shows the cyclic voltammogram of the 30 h ballmilled 60Li2S(cid:149)40SiS2 sample at a scan rate of 1 mV s21. The initial voltage of the test cell is 1.9 V vs. Li/Li1 electrode. In the ﬁrst step, the potential of the cell is cathodically swept to 20.5 V. A cathodic current peak is observed below 0 V during this sweep. The current corresponds to the deposition of metallic lithium on the nickel work- ing electrode. After that the direction of the voltage sweep is re- versed and the

voltage is anodically swept until 10 V vs. Li/Li1 electrode. During the anodic sweep, an anodic current peak is ob- served at around 10.3 V, and the anodic peak is attributed to the dissolution of the lithium metal that has deposited on the working electrode during the cathodic sweep. The ratio of the area of the anodic peak to that of the cathodic peak is 0.99. The results suggest that the ballmilled a-60Li2S(cid:149)40SiS2 sample has superior reversibil- ity of the deposition and dissolution

electrolytes for lithium batteries. Hence, the results shown conclude that the 60Li2S(cid:149)40SiS2 sample prepared by the ballmilling process has sufﬁcient electrochemical properties for use as a solid electrolyte for all-solid-state batteries.

B. For cell A a small polarization is observed for a very short period after the voltage is applied. After a little polarization at constant current more than 0.95 mA is observed while the voltage is applied. The dc conductivity is calculated to be 1.3 3 1024 S cm21 at room temperature from the observed current and the applied voltage. This dc conductivity is almost the same as the ac conductivity 1.8 3 1024 S cm21 mentioned previously. The difference between the dc and ac conductivities is

Preparation of LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 ﬁne powder.—XRD measure- ments conﬁrmed that the LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 powder prepared by oxalate decomposition has the layered a-NaFeO2-type structure with P3¯ m symmetry. The lattice constants of the obtained LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 sample are a 5 2.863I and c 5 14.163I and are well agreed with the reported values in some literature.42-45,52

Figure 5 shows the SEM image of the LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 sample. This image suggests that the particles of the obtained sample have hexagonal shapes and 1-2 mm diam as the average particle size. The average particle size is comparable to that of the solid electrolyte a-60Li2S(cid:149)40SiS2 (mol %) prepared by the ballmilling process.39,40 Consequently, the obtained LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 powder seems to be suf- ﬁciently ﬁne as electrode materials for solid-state batteries.

Charge-discharge properties of solid-state batteries.—An all- solid-state battery has been fabricated with the LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 sample, and the charge-discharge cycling test of the battery has been carried out under a constant current density of 64 mA cm22 ~C/30 in C-rate!. In this test charge-discharge criteria of voltage are set 3.8 and 2.0 V, respectively. prepared by oxalate decomposition methods at 800°C for 2 h. The a-60Li2S(cid:149)40SiS2 solid electrolyte showed high lithium-ion conduc- tivity 1.8 3 1024 S cm21 at room temperature and also showed high electrochemical stability. The LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 powder obtained by oxalate decomposition had ﬁne particle size 2 mm in diameter. The all-solid-state battery was fabricated with those materials and with indium foil as anode materials. The battery was prepared by successively pressing the cathode,

the solid electrolytes, and the anode at 300 MPa into a pellet of 10 mm diam. The battery showed good charge-discharge reversibility. The speciﬁc rechargeable ca- pacity of the LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 powder was about 98 mAh g21 in the solid-state battery. The charge-discharge efﬁciency was almost unity after the second cycle for the all-solid-state battery.

Figure 8. The charge-discharge cy- cling test was carried out under a constant current density of 64 mA cm22 and cutoff voltages of 3.8 and 2.0 V.

These results suggest that the LiCo0.3Ni0.7O2 ﬁne powders ob- tained by the oxalate decomposition methods have good electro- chemical properties as cathode materials for all-solid-state lithium batteries.
